prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB Millimeter Afterglow Detection
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum detection experiment of a target-of-opportunity GRB from an X-ray trigger. We require a JVLA observation within 3 days, placing a declination constraint of -30 to +25 deg. We will focus on dark, high-z and short GRBs. The RA and Dec are to be determined. We require one observation at 2-3 weeks to a depth of 30 uJy, and request an additional observation at a few days if feasible in the scheduling. For GRBs with a detection with CARMA or PdBI at early times, and for short GRBs, we only request a single ALMA observation to a depth of 20 uJy, resulting in the same overall time request per GRB.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: Our science goals require visit 2 at 2-3 weeks after the GRB trigger. The additional early visit at a few days postburst will significantly improve our ability to trace the circumburst density profile, but is not required for the other two science goals (energy, density). If we detect a GRB with PdBI or CARMA, we will only request the 2nd visit with ALMA. For short GRBs, we will detect a single epoch as soon as possible.

Our science goals require visit 2 at 2-3 weeks after the GRB trigger. The additional early visit at a few days postburst will significantly improve our ability to trace the circumburst density profile, but is not required for the other two science goals (energy, density). If we detect a GRB with PdBI or CARMA, we will only request the 2nd visit with ALMA. For short GRBs, we will detect a single epoch as soon as possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our science only requires continuum, and the precise frequency does not matter. Hence, our observations can utilize overhead of any other Band 3 continuum observations in the ALMA queue on the same day (e.g. bandpass, flux, and potentially pointing if other science targets are within 20 deg), greatly reducing the individual overhead for a given epoch. Therefore, our stated time in the Proposal Technical Justification is slightly less than calculated by the system.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request ALMA Band 3 observations of up to ten gamma-ray burst (GRB) in Cycle 2 to address fundamental physics in GRB science: What is the range of GRB explosion energies and what is the density and radial structure of the circumburst medium. To date, mm detections of GRB afterglows have been severely limited, resulting in a biased sample plagued with model degeneracies (e.g. between energy and density), but ALMA will solve this problem. Our laboratory for studying these questions will include high-redshift, "dark" (dust-obscured), and short GRBs, allowing us to also probe and pinpoint galaxies in the early universe and dust-obscured star formation. Furthermore, an ALMA detection of a short GRB will be the first mm detection since these events were discovered, with direct implications for electromagnetic follow-up of LIGO gravitational wave sources. To support the ALMA observations we formed an international collaboration with essential established access to radio facilities (Jansky VLA, PdBI, CARMA), large optical telescopes (Subaru, Gemini, Magellan, MMT, GTC), and X-ray satellites (Chandra, XMM), as well as theoretical experts in the field.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
